I have been starting to be more interested in cooking lately, especially how to properly heat a pan to get a good browning. i even got a pyrometer to find the temperature range but the emission values of stainless steel and oil make it impractical.

However I feel like my biggest issue is getting the right temperature. My stove goes from 1 to 9 and an extra "b" level. How can I imagine do these levels work? Is it like the speed of heating up? is there a target temperature that will be held on a certain level? all the manual tells me is the power of each level in kw. Is anyone familiar with these kind of stoves and can tell from experience how often you need to adjust the power and how these work?

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18886745
Some induction plates/hobs have thermometers and temperature settings on their controls. I even saw one with an in-built temperature probe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18886745
Just start cooking a bunch of different things on them. Put some butter in a pan and see how long it takes to stsrt sizzling. Throw veggies and oil in and play with different settings. I don't believe that cooking in a pan thinking things like I need to get my pan the 289.5 degrees F before putting the onions in and then raising the temp to 365 for 3.85 minutes, stirring 12 times per minute is the way to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18886745
>how to properly heat a pan to get a good browning
unironically easier than low heat long time cooking, just heat the pan until the Leidenfrost Effect happens, pic related, and that's about the perfect searing temperature. A good way to gauge this is to time how long it takes for a pan to heat to that. The difficulty in that is every pan takes a different amount of time as well as not all pans have consistent surface temperatures. Also depends on the thermal mass of the skillet. Anyways, that's way more information then necessary but you can get away getting a nice browning on food without getting it hot enough for the Leidenfrost Effect to happen. If you want to learn how to brown anything, learn about the Maillard Reaction.

No, kabaret is not a common food item here. I don't think I've seen it served once in my entire life. Regular sweet gelatine is more common than that.

Traditional norwegian food items consists of a lot of lamb and pig meat (made in any way but often cured or preserved in some way), fish, cheese, flatbread and regular bread, potatoes, root vegetables, game meat, pancakes, simple cakes and cookies, meatballs, berries and berry sauces, savoury sauces, porridge and other stuff that is eaten commonly all over europe.

This is very common, because ordinary people don't have the time, inclination, or live the kind of lifestyle where they would give a single shit about the subtle flavor of a consomme, and the work and expense involved. Pick anything really. This is where something that has an immediate visual wow, like a ratatouille, gets you points just because it looks like you gave a shit and did something other than put Hamburger Helper in a pan. Flavor is a big thing too, because so many people under-season their food. You throw a few jalapenos in something, and they're like woah, what's going on here. Learn your audience and cook for your audience, always. Otherwise you'll feel unrewarded working harder than you have to.

I will say though that generally if I make something I think is really good, the people I serve it to like it as well. Probably where this falls off is if I'm making something that is an acquired taste. Like I made a papaya salad that uses a lot of fish sauce and chilis. >go into store with $20
>buy $20 worth of individual packs of ramen I had not tried before
>try all of them
>decide what I liked from that bunch and took pictures of the package (because lol some of them don't have any engrish text)

>repeat process

>I prefer the cheese kind

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18884341
ok, first I chuckled, but then I realized you're not trolling, so lets break it down, shall we?
>fry some onions and garlic in butter
first of all, not some onions, but you caramelize onions.
second, not some garlic, but garlic and ginger, and you do these separetely, only for around 30 seconds or so, otherwise you will burn them.
And no, not butter, but ghee. If you don't have ghee, use regular oil, don't use butter, lol.
>add curry powder and let it combine and cook for a bit
wait, actually good advice? well, almost. for 500g of meat I recommend 2 tablespoons of good quality curry powder, but actually I recommend adding around 200ml of passata, cooking it for a couple of minutes, and then adding spices, which then you cook a bit more to get out their true flavours.
>add milk
for krishna's sake, never, absolutely, n e v e r add milk.
add chicken, then when no longer pink, dilute everything with a bit of water
>Then finish cooking seared chicken in it (thighs work great)
total gibberish, I'm not even bother deciphering it, it does says chicken though, so no, that's the wrong time to put the chicken in.
thighs do work great though. 5 points for slytherin (that's where I imagine you would be after writing such low quality recipe)
>Let the chicken simmer in there for 30 minutes
wtf, I love dry mushy chicken? just kidding, give it 20 minutes top.
>The curry powder thickens the sauce by itself so you don't have to do anything else to it.
o boy, there we go. curry powder will not thicken the sauce whatsoever. not even a bit, nope, runny, watery, curry on your way sir!
remember that mythical passata we added earlier? yep, that's your main thickener.
>Pile it on rice and w'Allah
first of all, you forgot to add a little bit of heavy cream, just a tad to mellow the spices.
and second of all, no, don't pile it on rice, pour it into a bowl and add a bit at the time on your rice platter, next to the rice. you want easy access to plain rice to cleanse the palette.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18884388
So to clarify you could put basically any combo of these ingredients and make a curry dish, probably by order of my listing. Honestly just looking at it, it's probably correct to assume greatest to smallest by volume added to the average dish.

If you already cook a decent amount you should have nearly all of this in your spice cabinet and fridge. Practice by looking up a few recipes, aloo gobi, aloo palak, saag paneer, vindaloo, etc. Then you'll get a sense for "this type of curry uses more cardamom" or "sri lankan curries use way more ground coriander:" Then once you cook a few of these and understand the flavor profiles you can cook basically any dish like that by feel. It's also wild because it actually shares a lot in common with many mexican dishes and chinese food. Idk why people try to make shit so complicated.

>jaggery is just sugar, black salt is just salt, hing tastes like shallots/onions
Wrong on every fucking count. Jaggery is sugar in the same sense that brown sugar is the same as white sugar. Black salt is mostly salt, but has a much different taste due to the other stuff in it and is not a good salt substitute. The flavor of hing is vaguely onion like, but the texture sure isn't like an onion's. You might as well say minced garlic and onion powder are the same.

While most of the things I listed are in garam masala, you're not going to be able to temper right without whole spices, and for that you're going to want things like whole cloves, whole cumin seeds, cinnamon, etc.

In conclusion, deal with it!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18885123
The sauce that makes up the curry is usually a very thick pureed vegetable stock made from onions, garlic, carrots, tomato and bell peppers that spices are then added to. The meat or veg of the dish is usually fried in ghee with a garlic & ginger puree, has about a tablespoon of whatever spice mixture is required for the dish and then 1/4 cup of condensed tomato paste and a couple of ladles of that vegetable stock are added in until they get the right consistency/colour. There's a lot more veg in an Indian curry than almost any other kind of takeaway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: So despite the fact that I hat wine I made some Peposo.
posts.com:
It was fucking delicious. Will be making it again. I wanted to use beef short ribs, but my butcher was sold out so I made it with some nice chuck. The sauce came out very similar in flavor to A1 steak sauce in my opinion. Different enough that it was its own thing, but thats a close enough comparison if you want an idea of the flavor.
>Slice chuck into 3" or so size chunks
>Heavily salt and pepper, sear in a blazing hot dutch oven
>Sear in batches to avoid overcrowding the pan
>Remove to a bowl after searing
>Toss in one thinly sliced yellow onion, pinch of salt
>Use water released from onions to deglaze
>Cook onions until golden, building more fond
>Move onions to sides of pot to make a well in the center
>Toss in an absolute FUCKTON of roughly, freshly cracked black pepper
>Not enough. Add more. However much you think is too much, double it.
>Let the pepper bloom for 30 seconds or so
>Toss in a heaping tablespoon of tomato paste, cook until darkened slightly
>Oven on 325F
>Deglaze with red wine, I used a chianti as it's the tradition for this recipe
>Return beef, get wine to just beneath level of beef, bring to a summer
>Pop in oven, lid on for 1.5 hours
>Take lid off, stir/flip meat
>Every 30 minutes stir
>Cook until tender, mine took 3.5 hours total
>If sauce reduce too much add some beef stock or more wine, I had to in the last 30 minutes
>Remove beef, strain sauce into sauce pan to remove all the spent onion goop and rosemary, bay leaves that I forgot to mention
>If sauce is too thin, reduce
>If sauce is too thick thin it out with stock/wine
>Once perfect consistency is achieved, replace beef until warmed through
I served it very rusticly with just some chunks of crusty bread, but for a meal that only cost about $35 for the chuck roast and a bottle of wine this was seriously luxurious eating. Try it. Not my pic, btw. Didn't take any and it's all been digested.

>>18877773
I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

there's a "tavern" just around the edge of walking distance from my house. like the sort of distance where when the weather's nice, a stroll over is excellent, but you wouldn't want to do it in the wintertime.

i put tavern in quotations because while they have some good beer and the food is pretty much pub-style, it's a bit more of a family friendly joint. fewer bitter alcoholics sitting at the small bar, more tables, and they also make their own ice cream so they have a little takeaway ice cream place built in to the place, off to the side.

the kids and i walk there, we sit, i order them a bunch of bullshit appetizers like homemade soft pretzels and mac and cheese. they do a double burger with a scotch egg on it, i eat that and drink a bunch of beer. buy the kids ice cream on the way out, they love it. the ice cream is dangerously legit. walk home, nice buzz, happy kids.

yeah, birthdays are pretty great.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
An egg dumplings recipe that my mother got from her grandmother which originated from either Germany or Russia. Can't remember where exactly. Simply take a couple eggs, a couple tablespoons of milk and cup or 2 of flour, beat the eggs and milk together, add flour and beat until thick, scoop out some portions and throw them into boiling water pot and cook for 15-30 minutes. When done cooking scoop out dumplings with spoon with a strainer to remove water and put in bowl applying butter and pepper to your liking.

Been thinking about changing the recipe up abit and adding more too it but I think it's pretty peak poor people food as is.

Second one I was spending the day at a friends house. They decide to go out to dinner to some pizza place. Told me it was a family thing and I could come along but couldn't eat with them I had to buy my own food.

i wasn't particularly poor myself but my parents both grew up either very poor or in a family massive enough to have to worry about food costs between so many kids. as a result they continued a habit as adults of buying the absolute lowest priced value foods to the cent they could find even though they never needed to by the time me or my brother were old enough to care. they were actually really resourceful when it came to cooking so the food was good but occasionally i got some unfortunate stuff such as

>meat frozen so long it tasted like nothing by the time we did eat it
>the occasional expired dollar store food, never understood this because there was a legitimate grocery store literally next door with comparable prices
>mom would always yell at me for taking a pack of 2 poptarts instead of just 1 to school at age 13, where my morning was basically leaving the house at 5am for a long ass bus trip and no school lunch until noon
>incredibly low amounts of salt or spices ever used, didn't grasp this until it clicked why homemade plain chicken tasted nothing like restaurant chicken
>yelling over who opened a cereal
>yelling over who finished a pack of anything, but also yelling over who left a small amount of a pack of anything
>insistence that the same coffee grounds be reused, i thought coffee was just shit water until adulthood because this was obviously not good
>the occasional bizarre leftovers creation that was hit or miss, later learned that this was usually a result of my dad being bored. he still does this to this day and it's usually something pretty cool nowadays but he holds himself to such a high standard and expectations for what amounts to "mix of whatever is in the fridge"

however there was some stuff i really did like that i still eat now that im on my own, like cheap frozen fish and pierogis.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not poor but I'm a social worker.
I've seen three "types" of home, in the first three family has some money but is dysfunctional, all the food is junk food, the freezer is full of pizza, the fridge is full of soft drink. This isn't nearly as expensive as you might imagine because of how calorie dense these foods acrually are. Kids skip meals, throw tantrums when food runs out, binge eat, get fat.

In the second type of home there's no money but at least one tired and stressed family member cooks. Often it's monotonous and totally unseasoned, boiled frozen vegetables, pasta, boiled eggs. Meat offcuts or frozen hotdogs in a pan, boiled potatoes. There's a variant for every ethnicity, but this is actually far better nutrition wise.

Third household is begging and stealing, everyone hoards and hides food, the only things in the fridge are moldy or fouled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18881748
Buy in bulk, even cheaper brands are fine even if they don't taste as much. They also last very long so you're not wasting any of it.
The money I save by buying slightly less quality meat for a month can be used to buy said oils and spices that will last several months so when you got that down upgrade meat as budget allows. We're not talking about a full cabinet of 20 spices either, just the most basic ones. I'm assuming salt and pepper are not included so rosemary, thyme, oregano, chili and one or two more after preference. Obviously you can't expect getting fresh stuff constantly unless planting it yourself.

I just know I'd prefer more basic meals with a larger choice of spices and oils to make variations than simply upgrading the meat quality slightly and not having said stuff. Worst case you can get piece by piece as budget allows since it, again, lasts very long (oils and spices).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18876648
Grew up fairly poor, 2 children single mom on teacher salary. I don't think there was really any consistent thread to what we ate. Mom cooked the vast majority of meals, either from scratch or instant, and we didn't eat much meat. The stuff she'd make from scratch was mostly soups and stews, and we ate a lot of rice and vegetables. We still could eat at mcdonalds or get pizza sometimes, but it was uncommon enough that it felt like a treat when we did. If there was anything that was missing it's snacks. She'd never buy soda, juice, cookies, or chips with the groceries. The only time we'd get a dessert after a meal is if we went to subway she'd get a single cookie to split between the three of us. If I went to a friend's house and they had snacks and sodas it seemed like the height of luxury. All in all I think she did a really good job since I only really realized how poor we were looking back on it. Even though she wasn't the greatest cook, food anxiety was never an issue for us and we developed fairly healthy eating habits.

>>18887112
ethanol boils at 78C, in cooking it’s not uncommon to reach those temperatures.
when the alcohol reaches it’s boiling point it starts evaporating rather quickly.
when the ethanol evaporates it goes from liquid to gas, and goes from being in your food to being in the air.
yes, there will still be a small amount left in the food, but not enough to have any noticable effect on your mind or body.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18887195
>in cooking it’s not uncommon to reach those temperatures
As it evaporates, it removes heat from what you're cooking, so it can "reach" that temperature, but it won't evaporate as quickly or as completely as you might think.

>food baked or simmered in alcohol for 15 minutes still retains 40 percent of the alcohol. After an hour of cooking, 25 percent of the alcohol remains, and even after two and a half hours there's still 5 percent of it

posts.com:
>>18884774
I like to think of spices in terms of combos. Spices themselves don't make a lot of sense (salt and pepper do not count) and in order for a dish to be tasty, combinations must be harmonious.

For example, cumin/ginger/a hint of cinnamon is a great combo. Depending on what dish you make, either saffron or nutmeg can be added. Also garlic.

Another more basic one is paprika/cumin in a 2/1 ratio, great for a protein + sauteed onion combo, such as chicken breasts or even steaks, or even for a minced meat spice mix. Cilantro can also be added for the latter two but not necessarily. Garlic can be added in all cases.


Of course, if you want to heat it up, you can always add some chilis.

I also have a few "additives" I tend to use, such as soy sauce instead of salt for chicke' based dishes, worcestershire sauce, MSG (in the form of bouillon cubes, Maggi, or plain).

There's also other stuff I use like classic mediterranean herbs, garlic and other crap but i usually just wing it.

>>18879090
I have this stuff, which, along with coconut oil is what everyone says to buy to make "movie theater popcorn". I very much disagree with this. Flavacol and coconut oil is what you should buy if you want your stovetop popcorn to taste exactly like microwave popcorn.

If you want good buttered popcorn, in my experience what you want is clarified butter. I would not buy it pre-made, either. The pre-made stuff tasted funky to me. It's easy to make, you just simmer the butter until the solids separate and then pour them off. Butter is really expensive right now, though.

Another tasty butter-based option is to use coconut oil or some other high-smoke-point oil, and then throw some fresh butter in right before it stops popping. This will make brown butter popcorn, which is good with some salt and sugar kettlecorn style. It has to go in right at the end though, or else it will burn.

You are essentially making what's called "aroma oil" in Japan/ramen world. You can get some good ideas if you search that.

The other cuisine that does something similar is Indian cooking. It's called tempering and you get oil super fucking hot then dump it all over a blend of herbs and spices. Once it cools some you pour that oil on top of whatever Indian sloppa you have made.

Both are really excellent additions to their respective foods.

what moka does differently is take away factors of control from your brew.
no: pressure, tamping, control of water input, control of water temperature, control of temperature of the overall vessel.

that in mind, espresso is not the be all end all of brewing methods. its a useful concentrated base drink to make many other drinks out of. but if you want the best out of your beans, you learn to do a proper pourover.

If you want single serve, I believe a standard ceramic v60 would do the trick. In my opinion, kalita wave style filters do best when there is an airgap on the sidewall, so i'm not too fond of my origami and prefer an actual wave or stagg x. Your personal taste will vary.

>>18873838
The silt is part of the experience for a french press, but if it really bothers you consider getting a 200 micron filter device. It feels kinda wasteful discarding some of your grounds, but will negate your issue. You can also use the filter to help prevent paper/cloth filter clogging.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18873838
Watch for fines in your grinds. Give the brewing grinds a stir and time to settle to the bottom. Pour slowly and maybe discard the last couple ounces. You might even also spoon off the first crema as I find that really improves the clarity of the cup. The FP shouldn't rely on the screen. It helps but gravity does most of your filtering.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18875263
There's really no point in spending more on a French Press. Most of the "premium" features you'd get on more expensive models (borosilicate or stainless vs cheap soda-lime glass; dual wall/insulation vs single wall; etc) are kind of pointless in a French Press. Because it's an immersion brewer, you shouldn't be leaving the grounds and water in there long enough for heat loss to be an issue, and even the cheapest, thinnest soda-lime glass won't experience catastrophic thermal shock at 100°C. Now, having said all that, if my cheap chinkshit French Press broke, I'd probably replace it with an Espro P3. I'd be interested in seeing how/if the dual mesh basket affects the brew.

Cool, dark, temp stable place. Opaque container would be ideal, but its more about minimizing air exchange for longer term storage. I use mason jars with (salvaged)one way valves for the coffees I'm currently resting, then divide them out into convenient portions to vac seal and freeze. The coffees I'm currently drinking are in kurasu cans. Bought them because they're cute, but I'd imagine the ceramic airscapes are much better.
https://espressoaf.com/guides/storage.html
https://youtu.be/K0JWuhE8a-w

Depends on the roast and how often you're exposing it to fresh oxygen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18879755
Sort of depends on what you want to drink, and how much work you're willing to put in to drink it. An Aeropress will get you brewed coffee; users will claim you can get espresso out of it, but they're going to hell for lying. It's far easier to use than a Mini/Nano, though. The Mini/Nano has the added benefit of taking pods, if you don't want to carry around a grinder or pre-ground coffee, but since it's closer to an actual espresso machine, it'll be more finnicky about temperature, while also being more work to produce coffee. I don't use either an Aeropress or a Mini/Nanopresso, but I do use a Picopresso as a daily driver espresso machine, but I can't imagine using that at school, but that machine is far more finnicky about all of the various coffee variables, since it's an actual espresso machine. For the record, I think Wacaco, the company behind all of the various [word for small]-presso products is also Chinese. And if you think a device similar to a Minipresso is a pain in the ass to use, I can't imagine a Mini or Nano being any less of a pain in the ass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18883844
Depends on other variables too. Things that increase extraction:
>more finely ground coffee
>darker roasts
>higher temperatures
>longer brew times
>larger amount of water (during brewing)
And the opposites decrease it obviously. You don't want your coffee to be over or under extracted so you need to find the right balance. Generally it's recommended to only fiddle with one variable at a time and keeping the rest consistent.

>Hey do you have any... wine?

>I dunno, just... wine.

>'I like Shiraz, do you have any?

>'Oh I don't know, we just sell wine. That's all I know.'

So, how can I hone in on which coffees I like and which I don't, so I can at least ask what they have and buy the kind I want, and maybe increase my enjoyment of coffee by about a solid 25%.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18872424
My research led me to discover this perfect recipe for short grain rice, but my rice cooker actually does a better job. My old zoji didn't, but this one does.

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.

>>18872761

39. We use the term “surrogate activity” to designate an activity that is directed toward an artificial goal that people set up for themselves merely in order to have some goal to work toward, or let us say, merely for the sake of the “fulfillment” that they get from pursuing the goal. Here is a rule of thumb for the identification of surrogate activities. Given a person who devotes much time and energy to the pursuit of goal X, ask yourself this: If he had to devote most of his time and energy to satisfying his biological needs, and if that effort required him to use his physical and mental faculties in a varied and interesting way, would he feel seriously deprived because he did not attain goal X? If the answer is no, then the person’s pursuit of goal X is a surrogate activity. Hirohito’s studies in marine biology clearly constituted a surrogate activity, since it is pretty certain that if Hirohito had had to spend his time working at interesting non-scientific tasks in order to obtain the necessities of life, he would not have felt deprived because he didn’t know all about the anatomy and life-cycles of marine animals. On the other hand the pursuit of sex and love (for example) is not a surrogate activity, because most people, even if their existence were otherwise satisfactory, would feel deprived if they passed their lives without ever having a relationship with a member of the opposite sex. (But pursuit of an excessive amount of sex, more than one really needs, can be a surrogate activity.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've cooked thousands of pizzas and there are some really nice looking ones in this thread.

I learned from https://varasanos.com/pizzarecipe.htm
I've been to the guys restaraunt as well, and while the crust was AAA+, I felt the rest of their pizza was lacking.
But then again, I'm a heathen who puts garlic in the sauce.

Key concepts:
- the hotter you can bake it, the better. At 750-800F you can get a beautiful paper thin char on the crust. I've used steel, baking stone, and even a 2$ paving stone from Home Depot that weighs like 25 pounds. The paving stone actually cooks great as long as you let it heat up enough. I don't double bake; I assemble the pizza and throw it in all at once.
- wetter dough is fluffier because of all the water turning to steam. It's harder to handle though if you're not experienced and it can stick to the surface that you're building the pizza on. This is just one of those things that you get better at as you gain experience.
- regular baking yeast cannot compete with sourdough for flavor, but the yeast is fast and has excellent handling properties.

DO NOT use grated cheese out of a bag. Grate your own from a block or ball. The shredded stuff in the bag is coated in some kind of powder to keep it from sticking together into one big ball, and this really seems to harm its melting properties. Basically, once it gets hot enough to melt and overcome the powder, the cheese often 'breaks' into a big greasy mess.

You dont need baking soda per se

You need a saturated fat, water (boiling so it gelifies the flour's startch on the spot) and salt. A ratio of about 30% fat at most to flour. 3% salt as well

They are, and they're great value for their quality as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18879577
If you ever wonder why Italians are anal about their food. This is why.

The original dish is called fegato alla Veneziana - Venetian style liver. You reduce Tropea (very mild) onions for 30 minutes in olive oil (from Garda lake) without letting them take any colour, remove them from the pan, turn up the heat and flash fry slabs (1cm thickness) of veal liver (the freshest possible) in the same pan. They should turn out rosé. Not saignant, not medium-rare, not rare. Rosé. Serve with the onions, freshly ground Lampong black pepper, sea salt and 25 yo aged balsamic vinegar from Modena. Serve with freshly ground polenta - mais sponcio (in the mountains surrounding Venice) or mais biancoperla (in the valley near the coast).

This dish has been maimed and killed, over and over and over again, for centuries. It's a children's favourite, when executed right. Which is rarely, if ever.

>>18861512
if its buds, 5g/100ml 80-85c, 15seconds then either +5 or +15 seconds with each additional steep. buds can get very bitter but i think they do better with longer gongfu steepings.
if its leaves the same but you can use full boiling, but tend to do better with shorter steeps. some people also simmer the leaves in a saucepan for a long time.

i find whites to be the hardest to brew right because they all seem to require different parameters where as black/oolongs/green ect call brew up well with the same parameters i.e all blacks behave the same, all whites behave differently at least for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18861512
>>18862215
You need to full soak the buds to get them to start extracting, which takes a pretty long time. Depending on your preference, you can do a fairly long hard rinse, boiling water for 30s or more depending on how dense your buds are, or you can do a short rinse, 5-10s at with boiling water, then a long brew, say 30s with boiling water. Once the leaves seem soaked through, they'll noticeably extract much faster. Do 10-15s brews here, if your tea is pleasant but thin, use more leaf, I brew with a very high ratio of leaf to water for baihao yinzhen. If it starts to be astringent or develop off flavors, you can do your main brews at around 90C instead. Once the leaves start to thin out, I like to do a single minute long brew, then a five minute brew and end it.

It will depend on the leaves you have, but the basic profile should look like that. Long brew to soak the leaves and get them to open up a bit, successions of much shorter brews, a few long brews. At close to boiling or boiling water, but feel free to lower the temperature if you feel you need to.

>>18871841
My biggest advice is that real, professional tasting is hard, and you shouldn't worry about giving brief or simple tasting notes. Trying to force it doesn't really work. When you're starting out you'll mostly give notes like woody, nutty, earthy etc. as you taste more stuff and have a better calibration, you'll start to find different sorts of flavors that can be consistent across different teas that you'll want to look for words to describe. I think it's fun, but a lot of the cultural and focus around tasting is people like Mei Leaf, who do it as a performance and not as any serious exercise. China has a robust culture around tea tasting and evaluation, but it mostly hasn't been exported from what I've seen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: what's the general difference in taste between small and large leaf ripe pu-erhs?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18873668
This is very general
Smaller leafs and buds, stronger, more bitter, infuses faster, runs out out flavor in less brews. Larger leaves + stems, sweeter, more mellow, smoother, less strong brews but more of them.
But its going to vary based on processing, fermentation level, the batch of tea leaves used etc.

- shitty quality tea leaves, usually from a bag
- not allowing the leaves room to expand, such as using an infuser basket
- adding too many leaves to the pot

Tea beginner here.
I tried and liked Bigelow's oolong, but Twinings is lighter, less earthy, and more of a green tea flavor to it. Is there supposed to be that much variation in oolong?
I prefer Bigelow's to Twining's here. What beginner-level brands should I look for?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18877041
oolong is one of the most varied categories of tea, because it can be more or less oxidized. the less oxidized stuff is closer to green tea, more oxidized to black tea generally. also, oolong can be roasted to various degrees, which can also change the flavor completely. there are many different types of oolong, some of them can be very fresh and smell of flowers and fruit, while others are bready, nutty, sweet or even minetal in taste

you generally shouldn't buy tea by prepackaged supermarket brands if you want to buy good quality stuff. you should be buying it from trusted vendors, who you can find in the pastebin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18877041
>Is there supposed to be that much variation in oolong?
yes you can get big variation in tea picked from the same mountain. oolongs typically come either as fermented 'green tea' or oxidised fermented 'black tea'
>What beginner-level brands should I look for?
loose will always be better than bagged, get a gaiwan or brewing basket that fits in your mug. vahdam is good for indian and sells on amazon, im guessing as your just starting out you wouldn't want to dive right in to importing from chinese suppliers. look out for iron goddess of mercy/Tieguanyin and Da Hong Pao/Big Red Robe. you'll be able to get both off amazon/tea houses/chinese stores although buying off an actual tea seller will give better quality and probably a little cheaper/quality

Put the tuo down with the dent on the bottom, go around about an inch from the edge with the pick and push downwards/pry outwards. Once you have the loosest tea around the edges removed you can either pry a layer off the top or just break the rest into chunks with your fingers.

>>18877797
This is King Arthur Flour's recipe, works like a charm. Differences though:
- Use a large star piping tip for the batter, pipe circles onto individual parchment sheets about 4 inches wide
- deep fry at 350° with veg/canola oil until golden brown
- glaze while still semi-warm so glaze looks purdy
- I like to use half butter and half lard for the batter, doughnuts turn out more fluffy.

OP, even restaurants give you access to the pepper and salt so that you can "season to taste".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other spices you might need to add at a certain point in cooking to maximize their flavor. And the recipe might have a certain ratio of those spices to achieve a certain flavor. Like you might like cinnamon, but if you use too much it will overpower the other flavors and wont taste like the dish youre supposed to be making anymore. But with salt & pepper, you can add them at the very end, even on individual plates. Just add them until you like the way it tastes, no need to overthink it. For me that's when a bite is noticeably salty and fairly spicy. The salt will also enhance the other flavors of the dish.

Another reason you want to salt to taste is there could be other variables adding saltiness to the dish, like broth, cheese, salted butter, and fermented sauces. If a recipe says to use a cup of chicken stock, they cant know how salty your stock is, so you need to figure out yourself how much more salt to add for it to taste good. If you relied on a predetermined measurement, you could end up with inedible saltiness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1/2 c butter
1/2 c packed brown sugar
1/2 c sugar
1 egg
1 tsp vanilla
1 tbsp milk
1 c flour
1/2 tsp baking soda
1/2 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp salt
1 c rolled oats
1/2 c raisins

- cream butter, add both sugars and cream
- beat in egg vanilla and milk till well combined
- mix flour, baking soda and powder, salt in a separate bowl, then add
- beat smooth, then add oats and raisins
- mix well, bake 11 ± 1 mins at 350
hope it works well for u anon :)

>>18861195
Didn’t drink until I was 17, at the after party to my high school ball (I guess burgers would call it prom). Then I got the taste for it.
Was fine for 2 years, alcoholic for 3, fine for another 3, alcoholic for another 3, and now I’m starting to clean up my act for my job. I know people here won’t sympathise or believe me, but my life has improved immensely in the last year through slow tapering.
I’m down to moderately drinking once a week, which is much better than being heavily dependant every day. It just took very small things like dropping a % per vol here and there, and buying slightly less every time you go to the shop.
I recently got back my taste for alcohol for the first time in god knows how long. I actually crave a good beer for the taste, or a good bourbon on the rocks.

tl;dr alcoholism sucks but you can still beat it by being smart. But I ain’t gonna blame you if you don’t want to, it’s your choice.

Portland Food Hall:

Pine Street Market:
https://www.pinestreetpdx.com/eateriesatpine

There's also this place called "The Zipper" that doesn't really have an online presence, but they have some cool micro restaurants. I go there with my gf when we visit her family.

There's a quite a few upscale food courts all over Portland though, and they're all great. It's kinda hard to recommend a specific restaurant since the vendors tend to rotate every couple months, but there's always something interesting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18882336
you won't get into kann for another six months.

portland is an amazing food city but it really depends what you're looking for. my number one pick for breakfast spot would have to be Gravy. the biscuits and gravy are the best in town and when my normie family flies out here they can't get enough. it can be difficult to get in on weekends though.

dinner? my rotating favorites AT THE MOMENT are:

Afuri (my enduring favorite, top tier ramen and japanese, the SE location has best ambiance and the onky properly made sushi in town)

EEM (don't expect thai takeout prices- this shit is another level and has been top of my list for years)

Dolly Olive (newer, amazing fresh pasta and focaccia, the chicken confit is really good too but in my opinion the pastas and salads are peak)

Scotch Lodge (incredible american/asian fusion- sounds like bullshit but it is outstanding.)

if you want like food trucks and shit it's hard to fuck up. you can fuck up, but you have to try. i hope you enjoy your time here.

You can make pour over filter coffee for about $20, the price of a Hario V60 (plastic, spend more if you hate plastics and need ceramic) and a pack of paper filters.

idk a recipe, really.
I'll try.
Black eyed peas cooked plain from a half pound dry
Two large chopped onions
8ish cloves of garlic, minced
8 ish chopped green goats horns (the long, curvy, wrinkly chillis)
A pound of blanched tomatoes
A peeled and chopped hand of ginger
Water, as needed
Like a half cup or more ooking oil or ghee
Various spices according to your tastes or family tradition. Mine is turmeric powder, cumin, mustard, caraway, saunth, hing, paprika, cayenne powder, neem leaves and prolly some other stuff in forgetting
Cilantro leaves

Put the cooked peas in a pot
Add water to cover
Boil
Reduce until thick and starchy; meanwhile, use the aromatics to make the wet masala then add it to the beans
Mix
Cook some more, adding water, if necessary
Temper the spices in the oil/ghee then pour into the curry
Stir to mix then serve, adding cilantro at the end

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I dont even like beans, but I could eat this for every single meal. The smoked ham hock or shank is essential. Also, I dont use a slow cooker, I throw it in a 325*F oven for like five hours.


2 tablespoons vegetable oil
1 large yellow onion, finely chopped
Kosher salt and black pepper
3 celery stalks, finely chopped
1 green bell pepper, finely chopped
10 garlic cloves, finely chopped
1 teaspoon garlic powder
1 teaspoon onion powder
1 teaspoon sweet paprika
½ to 1 teaspoon ground cayenne, plus more to taste
½ teaspoon ground sage (optional)
1 pound dried red kidney beans, soaked overnight
3 dried bay leaves
3 sprigs fresh thyme or 1 teaspoon dried thyme
12 ounces smoked pork sausage, preferably Andouille, sliced into 1-inch-thick coins
1 smoked ham hock or shanks (about 10 ounces)
Cooked rice, for serving
Sliced scallions, for serving
Louisiana-style hot sauce, for serving


Step 1
Heat the oil in a large (12-inch) skillet over medium. Add the onion, season with salt, and cook, stirring, until the onion is limp and translucent, 6 to 8 minutes. Add the celery and bell pepper and cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, 5 to 8 minutes. Add the chopped garlic, garlic powder, onion powder, paprika, cayenne and sage (if using); grind in a generous amount of black pepper and add ¾ teaspoon salt. Stir well to combine all the ingredients, then remove from the heat and scrape the mixture into a 6- to 8-quart slow cooker.

Step 2
Add the beans, bay leaves, thyme, sausage, ham hock and 6 cups water. Cook on high until the beans are very tender and creamy, about 7 hours.

Step 3
Before serving, add salt or cayenne to taste. Using a fork or the back of a spoon, mash some of the beans against the side of the slow cooker to make the mixture slightly creamy. (It will continue to thicken as it sits.) Discard the bay leaves and thyme sprigs; you can pick the meat off the ham hock if you like. Top the beans with hot cooked rice and scallions; serve with hot sauce.

For plain beans:

Soak them 6+ hours. You can let them soak up to 24 in my experience.

Dump out the water. Put them in a pot with new water. Bring to a boil for a minute or two. Reduce to a simmer. Add more water if needed. Taste the beans every so often to see if they're soft enough yet. Once they're soft enough, take them off the stove and drain the bean water.

>>18885235
Meat out on the tray! I patted down each piece and removed as much marinade as possible.

So, typically I use this roasting method:
>15 minutes 475F convention setting
>Lower temp to 350F
>10 minutes
>Flip and rotate, baste
>15 minutes
>Flip and rotate, baste
>15 minutes

A total of 55 minutes. That's how I was taught to do it. Today I'm trying a different method because I think all of that is not necessary. So, after putting a bit of water in the bottom of the pan (to prevent drippings from burning) I set the oven @ 350F convection setting (rather than conventional). I'm just going to keep an eye on it, but I suspect it will be ready to flip after 30 minutes.

>>18886570
So... I just wanted to say...

It may not seem ideal or important, but that water in the roasting pan is key.

If you just leave your roasting pan dry, it will carbonize and burn and taint the flavor of everything.

I feel mostly that people doubt this aspect. If you're trying this at home, don't doubt me on this. It is literally the most important aspect of it, and all at-home oven roasting.

If it weren't for that layer of water in the bottom of the pan, and the elevated rack, everything would be different in the worst way. The elevated rack protects whatever it is from DIRECT HEAT. And the water in the bottom protects whatever you're roasting from burnt flavors. If you tried this recipe without that bit of water, it would be so gross and bitter and burnt-tasting at the end that nobody would want to eat it.

This is basically the pinnacle of my at-home oven roasting skills. I hope I have taught ya'll, and documented with photos, the basis of at-home roasting.

I love you guys!

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18870294
I worked for an airline catering company. LSG. Bizarre how all that shit gets on and removed from flights. Most is frozen. Everything has strict specs for weight, count, etc. Fruit n cheese plates, salads, and first class for specific airlines is fresh made in house. Delta, United, Alaskan, and British Airways are pretty solid and fresh. Everything American Airlines is frozen. The bizarre amount of special meals available was irritating. Vegan, veg, Muslim, kosher, etc. Kosher meals came 100 percent frozen and shrink wrapped on serving trays. The rest are a pain. Nobody adhered to any of the Muslim meal/kitchen guidelines, but the end result fit the parameters.

there is so much talk of airplane food being bland, myself, i loved the airplane food, perhaps it was the excitement, civilian airplanes are in my eyes among the most beautiful machines man has ever built, sitting comfortably at ~10km altitude, oftentimes with a magical view, hearing the sound of the wind rushing over the airframe, hearing the muffled sound of people talking, having a trey served with various little food items.. to me, it was the whole package, it was the experience i appreciated, it crushes my soul that those days are vanishing, as if they never existed, oh how i yearn for the 80s and 90s, how i yearn for sitting next to someone i love, eating a meal, drifting away into fantasy-land, dreaming of the alien world ahead of me, perhaps we dont deserve such magic anymore, perhaps we never did, perhaps it was i that never deserved it

>>18885984
I haven't had an actual oven in two years now. I moved into a dilapidated apartment with a small kitchen. Less than half market rate per squarefoot for this area, but the place is a 19th-century tenement and management is stuck in the stone-age too. 1970's Kenmore range was truly disgusting, filled with dead roaches, and probably a deathtrap. Add to that that the natgas utility in my area is famously corrupt (in a famously-corrupt state) and will still charge you through the nose for "delivery and service fees" even if you used One Singular BTU per month. The building, naturally, has radiators, so cooking is the only thing I'd need gas for.

I got a two-burner induction cooktop and a convection toasteroven similar to the Breville in that image. I used an estimate of one year's savings on gas as my budget for the new appliances, and I don't miss the oven at all. Granted I'm not entertaining a crowd in my one-bed-one-bath apartment, but I'm actually quite proud of how well I've done with just this. It's safe, cheap, efficient, and the food comes out great. Being able to take a cast-iron skillet from the cooktop to the toaster oven honestly makes all the difference.

½ kilo boiled potatoes and boiled buckwheat

2 eggs

>>18879035
Very little meat. Very little cheese. Almost entirely plants. Most of their protein came from beans.
Mostly their diet consisted of extremely coarse, unpleasant barley bread (easier to grow than wheat, but it tastes bad).
Generally peasants wouldn't be malnourished– there'd be enough food for most of the year, but consistent periods of severe hunger during lean years. Medieval commoners were around 7 inches shorter on average than people are today.
All the animal products, nuts, and other proteins that allow people to grow to a healthy size were too resource intensive for the poor to afford; even those that could access them were often better off selling them for more grain.
This improved significantly after the black plague killed a third of the population. Europe was heavily overpopulated in the high middle ages relative to its technological carrying capacity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18879035
Due to crop rotation being necessary they ate a lot of beans and similar things. Bread being another staple, there is a reason they mention daily bread in the lord's prayer it's not just a metaphor. A lot of root vegetables during the winter, with a variety of seasonal crops. Fish was very important as well and a reason beyond trade for coastal cities being the largest in general.
As for meat most of the animals you raised for other things such as milk, wool and eggs so you would only eat them when they were too old to provide these things giving poor quality and though meat. So quality beef and lamb etc was pretty much only for the rich. Pigs however were raised for meat even by the lower classes as you could have them find food in woods you otherwise wouldn't get any food out of anyway. Hunted meat would also be had in the rural areas. A large part of why the norman king's forest laws were so hated in England were so hated is because it prevented the common people from having access to these two types of meat which they had earlier.
